article:
In linguistics, a 'consonant cluster' (or 'consonant blend') is a group of
consonants which have no intervening vowel. In English, for example, the groups
and are consonant clusters in the word splits.

Some linguists argue that the term can only be properly applied to those
consonant clusters that occur within one syllable. Others contend that the
concept is more useful when it includes consonant sequences across syllable
boundaries. According to the former definition, the longest consonant clusters
in the word extra would be and , J.C. Wells,
[http://www.phon.ucl.ac.uk/home/wells/syllabif.htm Syllabification and
allophony] whereas the latter allows . The German word AngstschweiÃ (;
"fear sweat") is another good example, with a cluster of five consonants: .
